[CHAPTER I. LAKṢAṆAPARICCHEDA]
[1. abhūtaparikalpa; a. sadasallaksaṇa]
tatra lakṣaṇam ārabhyāha /
body.translated_text:
[CHAPTER I. LAKṢAṆAPARICCHEDA]
[1. abhūtaparikalpa; a. sadasallaksaṇa]
tatra lakṣaṇam ārabhyāha /

children.text:
abhūtaparikalpo 'sti dvayan tatra na vidyate /
śūnyatā vidyate tv atra tasyām api sa vidyate // 1.1
children.translated_text:
abhūtaparikalpo 'sti dvayan tatra na vidyate /
śūnyatā vidyate tv atra tasyām api sa vidyate // 1.1
Mvbh 18

body.text: tatrābhūtaparikalpo grāhyagrāhakavikalpaḥ / dvayaṃ grāhyaṃ grāhakañ ca / śūnyatā tasyābhūtaparikalpasya grāhyagrāhakabhāvena virahitatā / tasyām api sa vidyata ity abhūtaparikalpaḥ / evaṃ yad yatra nāsti tat tena śūnyam iti yathābhūtaṃ samanupaśyati yat punar atrāvaśiṣṭaṃ bhavati tat sad ihāstīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānātīty aviparītaṃ śūnyatālakṣaṇam udbhāvitaṃ bhavati /
body.translated_text: There, the false conception is the delusion of the perceiver and the perceived; the duality is the perceived and the perceiver. Emptiness is the absence of the perceived and perceiver in that false conception. Even in that, it is found, thus it is the false conception. Thus, what is not there is empty, as seen in reality; what remains is existent here, as known in reality, thus the characteristic of emptiness is manifested without distortion.

children.text:
na śūnyaṃ nāpi cāśūnyaṃ tasmāt sarvaṃ vidhīyate /
satvād asatvāt satvāc ca madhyamā pratipac ca sā // I.2
children.translated_text:
na śūnyaṃ nāpi cāśūnyaṃ tasmāt sarvaṃ vidhīyate /
satvād asatvāt satvāc ca madhyamā pratipac ca sā // I.2

body.text: na śūnyaṃ śūnyatayā cābhūtaparikalpena ca / na cāśūnyaṃ dvayena grāhyena grāhakeṇa ca / sarvaṃ saṃskṛtaṃ cābhūtaparikalpākhyaṃ / asaṃskṛtaṃ ca śūnyatākhyaṃ / vidhīyate nirdiśyate satvād abhūtaparikalpasya asatvād dvayasya satvāc ca śūnyatāyā abhūtaparikalpe tasyāṃ cābhūtaparikalpasya sā ca madhyamā pratipat / yat sarvaṃ / naikāntena śūnyaṃ naikāntenāśūnyaṃ / evam ayaṃ pāṭhaḥ prajñāpāramitādiṣv anulomito bhavati sarvam idaṃ na śūnyaṃ nāpi cāśūnyam iti /
body.translated_text: Not empty by emptiness and false conception, nor non-empty by the duality of perceiver and perceived; everything is conditioned by what is called false conception, and unconditioned by what is called emptiness; it is prescribed and indicated due to the existence of false conception, the non-existence of duality, and the existence of emptiness in false conception, and in that false conception, it is the middle path. What is everything; neither entirely empty nor entirely non-empty. Thus, this reading becomes consistent in the <s>Prajñāpāramitā</s> and similar texts, that all this is neither empty nor non-empty.

evam abhūtaparikalpasya sallakṣaṇam asallakṣaṇaṃ ca khyāpayitvā / svalakṣaṇaṃ khyāpayati /

body.text: tatrārthapratibhāsaṃ yad rūpādibhāvena pratibhāsate / satvapratibhāsaṃ yat pañcendriyatvena svaparasantānayor [/] ātmapratibhāsaṃ kliṣṭaṃ manaḥ / ātmamohādisaṃprayogāt / vijñaptipratibhāsaṃ ṣaḍ vijñānāni [/] nāsti cāsyārtha iti / arthasatvapratibhāsasyānākāratvāt / ātmavijñaptipratibhāsasya ca vitathapratibhāsatvāt / (

children.translated_text: Mvbh 19

children.text: ) tadabhāvāt tad apy asad iti / yat tadgrāhyaṃ rūpādipañcendriyaṃ manaḥ ṣaḍvijñānasaṃjñakaṃ caturvidhaṃ tasya grāhyasyārthasyābhāvāt tad api grāhakaṃ vijñānam asat /
children.translated_text: Due to its absence, it is also non-existent. That which is grasped is the form and the five senses, the mind, the six consciousnesses named fourfold, due to the absence of the grasped object, that grasping consciousness is also non-existent.

body.translated_text: There, the appearance of the object is what appears as form and the like; the appearance of existence is what appears as the five senses in both self and others; the appearance of self is the afflicted mind, due to the conjunction with self-delusion and the like; the appearance of consciousness is the six consciousnesses; and the object of that does not exist, due to the formlessness of the appearance of object-existence, and the deceptive nature of the appearance of self-consciousness.

children.text:
abhūtaparikalpatvaṃ siddham asya bhavaty ataḥ /
na tathā sarvathābhāvāt /
children.translated_text:
abhūtaparikalpatvaṃ siddham asya bhavaty ataḥ /
na tathā sarvathābhāvāt /

body.text: yasmān na tathāsya bhāvo yathā pratibhāsa utpadyate / na ca sarvathābhāvo bhrāntimātrasyotpādāt/ kimarthaṃ punas tasyābhāva eva neṣyate / yasmāt /
body.translated_text: Because its being is not as it appears to arise; nor is there total non-existence due to the arising of mere delusion. Why then is its non-existence not asserted? Because,

children.translated_text: From its cessation, liberation is desired.

body.text: anyathā na bandho na mokṣaḥ prasidhyed iti saṃkleśavyavadānāpavādadoṣaḥ syāt /
body.translated_text: Otherwise, neither bondage nor liberation would be established, thus there would be the fault of contradicting affliction and purification.

body.translated_text: The nature is imagined meaning; the false conception is the dependent nature; the absence of perceiver and perceived is the perfected nature.

body.text:
[d. Asallakṣaṇānupraveśopāyalakṣaṇa]
idānīṃ tasminn evābhūtaparikalpe 'sallakṣaṇānupraveśopāyalakṣaṇaṃ paridīpayati /

children.text:
upalabdhiṃ samāśritya nopalabdhiḥ prajāyate /
nopalabdhiṃ samāśritya nopalabdhiḥ prajāyate // I.6
children.translated_text:
upalabdhiṃ samāśritya nopalabdhiḥ prajāyate /
nopalabdhiṃ samāśritya nopalabdhiḥ prajāyate // I.6

body.text: vijñaptimātropalabdhiṃ niśrityārthānupalabdhir jāyate / arthānupalabdhiṃ niśritya vijñaptimātrasyāpy anupalabdhir jāyate / evam asallakṣaṇaṃ grāhyagrāhakayoḥ praviśati /
body.translated_text: Relying solely on the perception of consciousness, the non-perception of objects arises; relying on the non-perception of objects, the non-perception of even mere consciousness arises. Thus, it enters the non-characteristic of perceiver and perceived.

body.text: upalabdhes tataḥ siddhā nopalabdhisvabhāvatā /
body.translated_text: From perception, the nature of non-perception is established.

body.text: upalabhyārthābhāve upalabdhyayogāt /
body.translated_text: Due to the non-existence of perceived objects, there is no conjunction with perception.

children.text: tasmāc ca samatā jñeyā nopalambhopalambhayoḥ // I.7
children.translated_text: Therefore, the equality of non-perception and perception is to be known.

body.text: upalabdher upalabdhitvenāsiddhatvād abhūtārthapratibhāsatayā tūpalabdhir ity ucyate 'nupalabdhisvabhāvāpi satī
body.translated_text: Perception is said to be perception due to its non-establishment as perception, because of the illusory appearance of non-existent objects, even though it is of the nature of non-perception.

body.text:
[e. Prabhedalakṣaṇa]
tasyaivedānīm abhūtaparikalpasya prabhedalakṣaṇaṃ khyāpayati /
body.translated_text:
[e. Prabhedalakṣaṇa]

body.text: abhūtaparikalpaś ca cittacaittās tridhātukāḥ /
body.translated_text: The false conception consists of mind and mental factors, and the three realms.

body.text: kāmarūpārūpyāvacarabhedena /
body.translated_text: By the divisions of desire, form, and formless realms.

body.text:
[f. Paryāyalakṣaṇa]
paryāyalakṣaṇaṃ ca khyāpayati /
body.translated_text:
[f. Paryāyalakṣaṇa]

children.text: tatrārthadṛṣṭir vijñānaṃ tadviśeṣe tu caitasāḥ // I.8
children.translated_text: There, perception of the object is consciousness; in its specific aspect, it is mental factors.

body.text: tatrārthamātre dṛṣṭir vijñānaṃ / arthaviśeṣe dṛṣṭiś caitasā vedanādayaḥ /
body.translated_text: There, perception of mere objects is consciousness; perception of specific objects is mental factors like sensation.

body.text:

pravṛttilakṣaṇaṃ ca khyāpayati /
body.translated_text:
[g. Pravṛttilakṣaṇa]

ekaṃ pratyayavijñānaṃ dvitīyam aupabhogikaṃ /
upabhogaparicchedaprerakās tatra caitasāḥ // I.9
children.translated_text:
ekaṃ pratyayavijñānaṃ dvitīyam aupabhogikaṃ /
upabhogaparicchedaprerakās tatra caitasāḥ // I.9

body.text: ālayavijñānam anyeṣāṃ vijñānānāṃ pratyayatvāt pratyayavijñānaṃ / tatpratyayaṃ pravṛttivijñānam aupabhogikaṃ / upabhogo vedanā / paricchedaḥ saṃjñā / prerakāḥ saṃskārā vijñānasya cetanāmanaskārādayaḥ /
body.translated_text: The consciousness of conditions is the <s>ālaya-vijñāna</s> as the cause for other consciousnesses; its condition is the active consciousness, experiential; enjoyment is sensation; delineation is perception; instigators are formations, consciousness, volition, attention, and the like.

body.text:

saṃkleśalakṣaṇaṃ ca khyāpayati/
body.translated_text:

pūraṇāt triparicchedād upabhogāc ca karṣaṇāt // I.10
children.translated_text:
chādanād ropaṇāc caiva nayanāt saṃparigrahāt /
pūraṇāt triparicchedād upabhogāc ca karṣaṇāt // I.10

body.text: nibandhanād ābhimukhyād duḥkhanāt kliśyate jagat /
body.translated_text: Due to binding, facing, and suffering, the world is afflicted.

body.text: tatra cchādanād avidyayā yathābhūtadarśanavibandhanāt / ropaṇāt saṃskārair vijñāne karmavāsanāyāḥ pratiṣṭhāpanāt / nayanād vijñānenopapattisthānasaṃprāpaṇāt / saṃparigrahān nāmarūpeṇātmabhāvasya / pūraṇāt ṣaḍāyatanena / triparicchedāt sparśena / upabhogād vedanayā / karṣaṇāt tṛṣṇayā karmākṣiptasya punarbhavasya [/] nibandhanād upādānair vijñānasyotpattyanukūleṣu kāmādiṣu / ābhimukhyād bhavena kṛtasya karmaṇaḥ punarbhave vipākadānāyābhimukhīkaraṇāt / duḥkhanāj jātyā jarāmaraṇena ca parikliśyate jagat / so 'yaṃ /
body.translated_text: There, due to covering by ignorance, obstruction of seeing reality; due to planting by formations, establishing the seeds of karma in consciousness; due to leading by consciousness, reaching the place of rebirth; due to appropriating by name and form, the existence of the self; due to filling by the six sense bases; due to threefold delineation by contact; due to enjoyment by sensation; due to pulling down by craving, the rebirth induced by karma; due to binding by clinging, consciousness arises in favorable conditions like desire; due to facing by becoming, the karma done faces the giving of result in rebirth; due to suffering by birth, aging, and death, the world is tormented. Thus, this is

children.text: tredhā dvedhā ca saṃkleśaḥ saptadhābhūtakalpanāt // I.11
children.translated_text: Affliction is threefold and twofold, due to the sevenfold false conception.

body.text: tredhā saṃkleśaḥ / kleśasaṃkleśaḥ karmasaṃkleśaḥ janmasaṃkleśaś ca / tatra kleśasaṃkleśo 'vidyātṛṣṇopādānāni / karmasaṃkleśaḥ saṃskārā bhavaś ca / janmasaṃkleśaḥ śeṣāṇy aṅgāni / dvedhā saṃkleśaḥ / hetusaṃkleśaḥ phalasaṃkleśaś ca / (

children.translated_text: Mvbh 22

children.text: ) tatra hetusaṃkleśaḥ kleśakarmasvabhāvair aṅgaiḥ phalasaṃkleśaś ca śeṣaiḥ / saptadhā saṃkleśaḥ saptavidho hetuḥ / viparyāsahetuḥ / ākṣepahetuḥ i upanayahetuḥ / parigrahahetuḥ / upabhogahetuḥ / ākarṣaṇahetuḥ / udvegahetuś ca / tatra viparyāsahetur avidyā / ākṣepahetuḥ saṃskārāḥ / upanayahetur vijñānaṃ / parigrahahetur nāmarūpaṣaḍāyatane / upabhogahetuḥ sparśavedane / ākarṣaṇahetus tṛṣṇopādānabhavāḥ / udvegahetur jātijarāmaraṇe / sarvaś caiṣa saṃkleśo 'bhūtaparikalpāt pravartata iti /
children.translated_text: There, the cause of affliction is by the nature of defilements and actions, and the result of affliction is by the rest; affliction is sevenfold due to sevenfold causes: the cause of misapprehension, the cause of projection, the cause of leading, the cause of appropriation, the cause of enjoyment, the cause of attraction, and the cause of agitation. There, ignorance is the cause of misapprehension; formations are the cause of projection; consciousness is the cause of leading; name and form with the six bases are the cause of appropriation; contact and sensation are the cause of enjoyment; craving, clinging, and becoming are the cause of attraction; birth, aging, and death are the cause of agitation. All this affliction arises from the false conception.

body.translated_text: tredhā saṃkleśaḥ / kleśasaṃkleśaḥ karmasaṃkleśaḥ janmasaṃkleśaś ca / tatra kleśasaṃkleśo 'vidyātṛṣṇopādānāni / karmasaṃkleśaḥ saṃskārā bhavaś ca / janmasaṃkleśaḥ śeṣāṇy aṅgāni / dvedhā saṃkleśaḥ / hetusaṃkleśaḥ phalasaṃkleśaś ca / (

body.text: dvayābhāvo hy abhāvasya bhāvaḥ śūnyasya lakṣaṇaṃ /
body.translated_text: The absence of duality is indeed the presence of absence, the characteristic of emptiness.

body.text: dvayagrāhyagrāhakasyābhāvaḥ / tasya cābhāvasya bhāvaḥ śūnyatayā (

children.translated_text: Mvbh 23

children.text: ) lakṣaṇam ity abhāvasvabhāvalakṣaṇatvaṃ śūnyatāyāḥ paridīpitaṃ bhavati / yaś cāsau tadabhāvasvabhāvaḥ sa /
children.translated_text: Thus, the characteristic of the nature of absence is elucidated as emptiness; and that which is of the nature of that absence is

body.translated_text: The absence of perceiver and perceived; and the presence of that absence is emptiness,

body.text: na bhāvo nāpi cābhāvaḥ /
body.translated_text: neither being nor non-being.

body.text: kathaṃ na bhāvo yasmāt dvayasyābhāvaḥ / kathaṃ nābhāvo yasmāt dvayābhāvasya bhāvaḥ / etac ca śūnyatāyā lakṣaṇaṃ / tasmād abhūtaparikalpān
body.translated_text: How is it not being? Because of the absence of duality. How is it not non-being? Because of the presence of the absence of duality. This is the characteristic of emptiness. Therefore, from the false conception,

body.translated_text: The fetters become the covering. The fetter of conceit is the covering in the understanding of the view of the body, due to the persistence of the inner and outer self-conceit at the time of realization, due to not abandoning it. The fetter of ignorance is the covering in the understanding of the object of the view of the body, due to not understanding the aggregates of clinging. The fetter of view is the covering in the understanding of the truth of cessation, due to fear from the views of the body and eternal grasping, and due to criticism by wrong view. The fetter of attachment is the covering in the understanding of the truth of the path, due to attachment to purity of grasping otherwise. The fetter of doubt is the covering in the understanding of the three jewels, due to lack of faith in their virtues. The fetter of jealousy is the covering in the understanding of gain and honor, due to the perception of their faults. The fetter of stinginess is the covering in the understanding of simplicity, due to the resolution in purification.

children.translated_text: and also of perceiver and perceived, and of existence and non-existence, the vision.

children.text: yajjñānān na pravarteta tad dhi tatvasya lakṣaṇaṃ /
children.translated_text: That which does not arise from knowledge is indeed the characteristic of reality.

body.text: pudgaladharmayoḥ samāropāpavādadarśanaṃ yasya jñānān na pravartate / tat parikalpitasvabhāve tatvalakṣaṇaṃ / grāhyagrāhakayoḥ samāropāpavādadarśanaṃ yasya jñānān na pravartate / tat paratantrasvabhāve tatvalakṣaṇaṃ / bhāvābhāvasamāropāpavādadarśanaṃ yasya jñānān na pravartate / tat pariniṣpannasvabhāve tatvalakṣaṇaṃ / etan mūlatatve lakṣaṇam aviparītaṃ lakṣaṇatatvam ity ucyate /
body.translated_text: The vision of imposition and refutation of individuals and <s>dharmas</s> that does not arise from knowledge is the characteristic of reality in the imagined nature. The vision of imposition and refutation of perceiver and perceived that does not arise from knowledge is the characteristic of reality in the dependent nature. The vision of imposition and refutation of existence and non-existence that does not arise from knowledge is the characteristic of reality in the perfected nature. In this fundamental reality, the characteristic is non-distorted, thus it is called characteristic reality.

children.translated_text: Suffering is known as the characteristic of grasping, and it is considered another by connection.

body.text: mūlatatve yathākramaṃ duḥkham upādānataḥ pudgaladharmābhiniveśopādānāt / lakṣaṇatas triduḥkhatālakṣaṇatvāt / saṃbandhataś ca duḥkhasaṃbandhāt [/] tatraiva mūlatatve yathākramaṃ veditavyam /
body.translated_text: In fundamental reality, sequentially, suffering is due to grasping from the attachment to individuals and <s>dharmas</s>; by characteristic, it is the characteristic of the threefold suffering; and by connection, it is the connection with suffering. In that very fundamental reality, it is to be known sequentially.

body.text: abhāvaś cāpy atadbhāvaḥ prakṛtiḥ śūnyatā matā /
body.translated_text: Absence and indeed the non-being, nature is considered emptiness.

body.text: parikalpitalakṣaṇaṃ na kenacit prakāreṇāstīty abhāva evāsya śūnyatā paratantralakṣaṇaṃ tathā nāsti yathā parikalpyate na tu sarvathā nāstīti tasyātadbhāvaḥ (/) śūnyatā [/] pariniṣpannalakṣaṇaṃ śūnyatāsvabhāvam eveti prakṛtir evāsya śūnyatā /
body.translated_text: The characteristic of the imagined does not exist in any way, thus its emptiness is absence. The characteristic of the dependent does not exist as imagined, yet it is not entirely non-existent, thus its non-being is emptiness. The characteristic of the perfected is indeed the nature of emptiness, thus its nature itself is emptiness.

children.text: alakṣaṇaṃ ca nairātmyaṃ tadvilakṣaṇam eva ca // III.7
children.translated_text: Non-characteristic and non-self, and indeed distinct from that.
And the specific characteristic is indicated.

body.text: parikalpitasya svabhāvasya lakṣaṇam eva nāstīty alakṣaṇam evāsya nairātmyaṃ [/] paratantrasyāsti lakṣaṇaṃ na tu yathā parikalpyata iti tadvilakṣaṇam asya lakṣaṇan nairātmyaṃ / pariniṣpannas tu svabhāvo nairātmyam eveti prakṛtir evāsya nairātmyam iti trividhe mūlatatve trividhānityatā paridīpitā asadarthānityatā utpādabhaṅgānityatā samalanirmalānityatā ca / trividhā duḥkhatā upādānaduḥkhatā lakṣaṇaduḥkhatā saṃbandhaduḥkhatā (

children.text: ) ca / trividhā śūnyatā abhāvaśūnyatā atadbhāvaśūnyatā svabhāvaśūnyatā ca trividhaṃ nairātmyaṃ alakṣaṇanairātmyaṃ / vilakṣaṇanairātmyaṃ svalakṣaṇanairātmyaṃ ca /
children.translated_text: And the threefold emptiness is absence emptiness, non-being emptiness, and nature emptiness. The threefold non-self is non-characteristic non-self, distinct non-self, and specific characteristic non-self.

body.translated_text: The characteristic of the imagined nature does not exist, thus its non-characteristic is non-self. The dependent nature has a characteristic, but not as imagined, thus its distinct characteristic is non-self. The perfected nature is indeed non-self, thus its nature itself is non-self. In the threefold fundamental reality, the threefold impermanence is elucidated: impermanence of non-existent meaning, impermanence of arising and decay, and impermanence of impurity and purity. The threefold suffering is suffering of grasping, suffering of characteristic, and suffering of connection.

children.translated_text: By the completion of non-distortion and non-transformation, it is twofold.

[10. Kauśalyatattva]
kauśalyatatvaṃ darśanapratipakṣeṇety uktaṃ / katham eṣu skandhādiṣu daśavidham ātmadarśanam /

children.translated_text: In singular causality, enjoyership, agency, and control,
in sovereignty, eternity, affliction, purity, and support as well.
In yogic state, non-liberation, and liberation, indeed the view of self is in these.

body.translated_text:
[10. Kauśalyatattva]
kauśalyatatvaṃ darśanapratipakṣeṇety uktaṃ / katham eṣu skandhādiṣu daśavidham ātmadarśanam /

body.text: eṣa daśavidha ātmāsadgrāhaḥ skandhādiṣu pravartate / yasya pratipakṣeṇa daśavidhaṃ kauśalyaṃ yad utaikatvagrāho hetutvagrāho bhoktṛtvagrāhaḥ / kartṛtvagrāhaḥ / svatantragrāhaḥ i adhipatitvagrāho nityatvagrāhaḥ / saṃkliṣṭavyavadānatvagrāho yogitvagrāhaḥ / amuktamuktatvagrāhaś ca /
body.translated_text: This tenfold false grasping of self operates in the aggregates and others, against which there is tenfold skillfulness, namely the grasping of unity, causality, enjoyership, agency, independence, sovereignty, eternity, affliction-purification, yogic state, and non-liberation-liberation.

body.text: katham idaṃ daśavidhaṃ kauśalyatatvaṃ mūlatatve 'ntarbhavati / yatas triṣu svabhāveṣu te skandhādayo 'ntarbhūtāḥ / katham antarbhūtāḥ /
body.translated_text: How does this tenfold reality of skillfulness include in fundamental reality? Because in the three natures, those aggregates and others are included. How are they included?

children.translated_text: By the imagined, conceptualized, and dharma nature meaning, in them are they.

body.text: trividhaṃ rūpaṃ parikalpitaṃ rūpaṃ yo rūpasya parikalpitaḥ svabhāvaḥ / vikalpitaṃ rūpaṃ yo rūpasya paratantraḥ (/) svabhāvas tatra hi rūpavikalpaḥ kriyate / dharmatārūpaṃ yo rūpasya pariniṣpannaḥ svabhāvaḥ / yathā rūpam evaṃ vedanādayaḥ skandhāḥ dhātvāyatanādayaś ca yojyāḥ / evan triṣu svabhāveṣu skandhādīnām antarbhāvād daśavidhaṃ kauśalyatatvaṃ mūlatatva eva draṣṭavyaṃ / uktam idaṃ yathā daśavidhātmadarśanapratipakṣeṇa skandhādikauśalyaṃ [/] skandhādyarthas tu noktaḥ / sa idānīm ucyate/
body.translated_text: The form is threefold: the imagined form is that whose nature is imagined; the conceptualized form is that whose nature is dependent, where indeed the form is conceptualized; the dharma nature form is that whose nature is perfected. Just as form, so are sensation and other aggregates, elements, and sense bases to be connected. Thus, due to inclusion in the three natures of the aggregates and others, the tenfold reality of skillfulness is to be seen in fundamental reality. This is stated as how the tenfold skillfulness in opposition to the view of self in aggregates and others is to be understood; but the meaning of aggregates and others has not been stated. It is now stated.

body.text: [a. Skandhārtha]

children.translated_text: Initially, for the purpose of multiplicity, summary, and delineation.

body.translated_text: [a. Meaning of Aggregates]

body.text: āditas tāvat skandhās te trividhenārthena veditavyāḥ / anekatvārthena yat kiñcid rūpam atītānāgatapratyutpannam iti vistaraḥ / abhisaṃkṣepārthena tat sarvam aikadhyam abhisaṃkṣipyeti / paricchedārthena ca rūpādilakṣaṇasya pṛthaktvavyavasthānāt / rāśyartho hi skandhārtha evaṃ ca loke rāśyartho dṛṣṭa iti /
body.translated_text: Firstly, the aggregates are to be understood by threefold meaning: by the meaning of multiplicity, whatever form is past, future, or present, in detail; by the meaning of summary, all that is condensed into unity; and by the meaning of delineation, by the establishment of the distinction of characteristics like form. For the meaning of heap is indeed the meaning of aggregates, and thus in the world, the meaning of heap is seen.

body.text: [b. Dhātvartha]

children.translated_text: Another meaning is considered as perceiver, perceived, and the seed of that perception.

body.translated_text: [b. Meaning of Elements]

body.text: katamo 'paro dhātus tatra grāhakabījārthaḥ cakṣurdhātvādayaḥ [/] grāhyabījārtho rūpadhātvādayas [/] tadgrāhabījārthaś cakṣurvijñānadhātvādayaḥ /
body.translated_text: Which is the other element there? The meaning of perceiver seed is the eye element and others; the meaning of perceived seed is the form element and others; the meaning of the seed of that perception is the eye consciousness element and others.

body.text: [c. Āyatanārtha]

children.translated_text: Another is through the door of delineation and enjoyment of known objects.

body.translated_text: [c. Meaning of Sense Bases]

body.text: kim aparaṃ āyatanaṃ / tatra veditopabhogāyadvārārthena ṣaḍ ādhyātmikāny āyatanāni / arthaparicchedopabhogāyadvārārthena ṣaḍ bāhyāni /
body.translated_text: What is the other sense base? There, by the meaning of the door of delineation and enjoyment of known objects, there are six internal sense bases; by the meaning of the door of delineation and enjoyment of objects, there are six external sense bases.

children.translated_text: The refutation of cause is due to the imagination of causelessness; the imposition of effect is due to the imagination of the activity of ignorance and other conditions in formations and others; the refutation of effect is due to the imagination that there are no conditions of ignorance and others in formations and others. The imposition of action is due to the imagination of activity in the arising of ignorance and others in formations and others; the refutation of action is due to the imagination of lack of capability, thus the non-imposition and refutation are to be known.

body.translated_text: The meaning of non-imposition and refutation of cause and effect actions is the meaning of dependent origination. There, the cause is not imposed due to the imagination of the discordant cause of formations and others.

body.translated_text: [e. Meaning of Place and Non-place]

body.text: sthānāsthānaṃ saptavidhapāratantryārthena veditavyaṃ / tatrāniṣṭe pāratantryaṃ duścaritenānicchato 'pi durgatigamanād iṣṭe pāratantryaṃ sucaritena sugatigamanāt / viśuddhau pāratantryaṃ pañca nivaraṇāny aprahāya yāvat saptabodhyaṅgāny abhāvayitvā duḥkhasyāntākaraṇāt samotpattau pāratantryaṃ dvayor apūrvācaramayos tathāgatayoś cakravartinoś caikasmin lokadhātāv anutpādād ādhipatye pāratantryaṃ striyāś cakravartitvādyakaraṇāt saṃprāptau pāratantryaṃ striyāḥ pratyekānuttarabodhyanabhisaṃbodhāt samudācāre pāratantryaṃ dṛṣṭisaṃpannasya vadhādyupakramāsamudācārāt pṛthagjanasya ca samudācārād vistareṇa bahudhātukasūtrānusārād anugantavyaṃ /
body.translated_text: Place and non-place are to be understood by the sevenfold meaning of dependence. There, in the undesirable, dependence is due to bad conduct leading to an unwanted rebirth; in the desirable, dependence is due to good conduct leading to a good rebirth; in purity, dependence is due to not abandoning the five hindrances until cultivating the seven factors of enlightenment, ending suffering; in co-arising, dependence is due to the non-arising of both the unprecedented and the ordinary, of <s>Tathāgata</s>s and <s>Chakravartin</s>s in a single world realm; in sovereignty, dependence is due to a woman not performing the acts of a <s>Chakravartin</s>; in attainment, dependence is due to a woman not realizing the unsurpassed enlightenment of a <s>Pratyekabuddha</s>; in conduct, dependence is due to the non-engagement in acts like killing by one endowed with vision, and the engagement by ordinary persons, as extensively followed in the <s>Bahudhātuka Sūtra</s>.

body.text: kim aparaṃ satyacatuṣṭayaṃ / tatra duḥkhasatyaṃ vedanāsanimittārthena yat kiñcid veditam idam atra duḥkhasyeti kṛtvā vedanānimittaṃ punar vedanāsthānīyā dharmā veditavyāḥ / tannimittapratipattitaḥ samudayasatyaṃ duḥkhasatyanimittaṃ yā pratipattiḥ / tayoḥ śamārthena nirodhasatyaṃ / pratipakṣārthena mārgasatyaṃ /
body.translated_text: What is the other fourfold truth? There, the truth of suffering is by the meaning of sensation as the cause, considering whatever is known here as suffering; again, by the cause of sensation, the <s>dharmas</s> substituting for sensation are to be known. By the realization of that cause, the truth of origin is the realization of the cause of the truth of suffering. By the meaning of peace of those two, the truth of cessation. By the meaning of the counteragent, the truth of the path.

body.translated_text: the conditioned and unconditioned there, the designation is name, body, and others, the cause is the <s>ālaya-vijñāna</s> grasped as a seed; the sign is grasped by the body of establishment; the conceptualization of grasp is grasped by the consciousness of activity; this, with designation and cause, is the sign with conjunction to be understood as conditioned. There, the mind is that which is always of mental form; the grasp is the body of the five consciousnesses; the conceptualization is the mind consciousness, due to its conceptual nature, it is unconditioned again, and peace is cessation. The purpose of peace is suchness; there, peace is cessation, and the path is what is peace, by which it is, considering that the purpose of peace is suchness, because the path is the support of suchness, and the path's nature is peace, by that peace.

body.translated_text: There, the state of cause is the entry state of a person of lineage, the application state of one who has generated <s>bodhicitta</s> from its generation onwards until the result is attained; the result state is when attained; the state of what is to be done is of the trainee; the state of what is not to be done is of the non-trainee; the special state is of one endowed with special qualities like supernormal knowledge; the superior state is of a <s>Bodhisattva</s> who has entered the grounds beyond <s>Śrāvaka</s>s and others; the unsurpassed state is of the Buddha, beyond which there is no state. The state of resolution is for <s>Bodhisattva</s>s in the entire realm of resolution practice; the entry state is on the first ground; the liberation state is in the subsequent six grounds; the prediction state is on the eighth ground; the discourse state is on the ninth; the consecration state is on the tenth; the attainment state is the <s>dharmakāya</s> of the Buddhas; the benefit state is the enjoyment body; the performance of duties state is the emanation body. All these are to be understood as various states.

body.text: aviparyāsānāṃ piṇḍārthaḥ / vyañjanāviparyāsena śamathanimittaṃ pratividhyati / arthāviparyāsena vipaśyanānimittaṃ pratividhyati / manaskārāviparyāsena viparyāsanidānaṃ parivarjayati / avisārāviparyāsena tannimittaṃ sugṛhītaṃ karoti / svalakṣaṇāviparyāsena tatpratipakṣeṇāvikalpaṃ mārgaṃ bhāvayati / sāmānyalakṣaṇāviparyāsena vyavadānaprakṛtiṃ pratividhyati / aśuddhiśuddhimanaskārāviparyāsena tadāvaraṇaprahīṇāprahīṇatāṃ prajānāti / tadāgantukatvāviparyāsena saṃkleśavyavadānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti / atrāsānunnatyaviparyāsena nirāvaraṇe niryāti /
body.translated_text: Summary of non-distortions: By the non-distortion of expression, he realizes the object of <s>śamatha</s>; by the non-distortion of meaning, he realizes the object of <s>vipaśyanā</s>; by the non-distortion of attention, he avoids the cause of distortion; by the non-distortion of non-diffusion, he makes that object well grasped; by the non-distortion of specific characteristic, he cultivates the non-conceptual path as its counteragent; by the non-distortion of general characteristic, he realizes the nature of purification; by the non-distortion of attention to impurity and purity, he knows the abandonment and non-abandonment of that covering; by the non-distortion of adventitiousness, he knows affliction and purification as they are; by the non-distortion of fear and elevation, he proceeds without covering.

body.text: ānuttaryaparicchedaḥ pañcamaḥ //
body.translated_text: The fifth is the distinction of the supreme.
